awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research:  Cognitive deficiency as a source of reproductive isolation between hybridizing species
awd_abstract_narration:
When different species breed with each other, or hybridize, the two original species can lose their distinctiveness unless hybrids become disadvantaged and less fit than their parents. Most research into hybrid disadvantage has focused on hybrid sterility or embryonic developmental problems. However, reductions in cognitive abilities such as learning and memory could also cause disadvantages for hybrids. Learning and memory are important for many species, but whether deficits in hybrids' learning and memory can function in keeping species separate is unknown. This collaborative project will evaluate the possibility that learning and memory deficiencies maintain the species boundary between hybridizing chickadee species. This work will fill an important void in our understanding of the development and maintenance of species, a fundamental evolutionary process. It will inspire new avenues of research in evolution, behavior, and neuroscience. The research also has important implications for the conservation of biodiversity. With this project, the researchers will train postdoctoral and graduate students. Additionally, underrepresented undergraduate students will gain integrative training in research and science communication. Students involved in mentored research at each institution during the academic year will work on a different aspect of the project at one of the other involved institutions during the summer. As a part of the summer experience, the students will collaborate with the Bird Academy at the Cornell Lab of Ornithology to develop a high-traffic online module on bird hybridization. They will therefore learn to employ diverse research approaches to address a common question, and to communicate science to the public. 

How learning and memory function in hybrids is relatively unexplored. These traits have been shaped by natural selection, but their role in the maintenance of species boundaries is unknown. The overall objective of the proposed research is to integrate behavior with neuroanatomy and genomics to evaluate the potential for hybrid deficiencies in cognitive ability to contribute to postzygotic reproductive isolation. Using naturally-hybridizing black-capped and Carolina chickadees, the proposed research will test the central hypothesis that selection acts against hybrids deficient in memory and learning, and that these deficiencies are reflected in neuroanatomic and genomic variation. This system is well suited for testing the role of cognition in postzygotic reproductive isolation because learning and memory are important for fitness in both species. Preliminary data suggest that hybrid chickadees have deficient memories and small hippocampal neurons, and that genes linked to learning and memory are involved in reproductive isolation. The research team will address the central hypothesis in an eastern Pennsylvania hybrid zone transect. With behavioral tests of learning and memory, comparative neuroanatomy, RNA sequencing, and whole-genome resequencing, the research will: 1) determine the relative learning and memory abilities of black-capped, Carolina, and hybrid chickadees; 2) quantify neuroanatomic differences between hybrid and parental-species chickadees; and 3) identify signatures of reproductive isolation and misexpression in genes underlying cognition. Through the completion and integration of these aims, this research will connect cognition with speciation in the first test of hybrid learning and memory deficiency as a postzygotic reproductive isolating barrier.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
How learning and memory function in hybrid individuals is completely unknown. Behavioral and neurological studies suggest that these traits have been shaped by natural selection, but the role of learning and memory in the maintenance of species boundaries has yet to be investigated. When hybridization occurs, selection against hybrids (i.e., postzygotic reproductive isolation) reduces gene flow and prevents species fusion. The importance of learning and memory for fitness is well documented, but its contribution to selection against hybrids has never been explored. Our overall objective for this research was to evaluate the potential for reduced cognitive abilities in hybrids to contribute to postzygotic reproductive isolation. To do this, we investigated the behavior, neuroanatomy, and genomics of naturally occurring black-capped and Carolina chickadees and their hybrids. 

One outcome of this research was our finding that the relative performance of hybrids on a variety of cognitive tests varies depending on whether the chickadees being tested were caught in the wild versus raised under common conditions. For example, chickadees raised under common conditions were equally likely to solve a problem, whether they were hybrids or not. However, wild-caught hybrid chickadees were less likely to solve a problem than were wild-caught black-capped or Carolina chickadees. These results suggest that aspects of the environment and/or quality of parental care may impact cognitive abilities, with a greater impact on hybrids.

Another outcome of this research was finding that many polymorphisms in the genome are associated with performance on multiple cognitive tests, and that some of these polymorphisms are associated with genes that are expressed in the brain or involved in the function or development of the nervous system. The genotypes of wild-caught chickadees at these loci may contribute to reduced cognitive abilities, leading to selection, particularly under certain environmental conditions. 

In additional to multiple research findings, this project also produced several important educational outcomes. Many undergraduates from diverse backgrounds contributed to this project, and therefore gained important exposure to research, and training in multiple biology methods. These undergraduates went on to graduate school, medical school, dental school, as well as employment. Two PhD students and six MS students were involved with these projects, as were four postdoctoral researchers. Finally, we collaborated with an education studio to produce a freely available set of high school lesson plans on hybridization. These lesson plans introduce important concepts, connecting them to the students’ experiences in the real world, while also highlighting the potential for people from diverse backgrounds to become scientists.
